description: From Middle English deie, from Old English dēah, dēag (“color, hue, dye”), from Proto-Germanic *daugō (“colour, shade”), from *dauganą, *dug- (“to conceal, be dark”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰewh₂- (“to smoke, raise dust, camouflage”).
The verb is from Middle English deien, from Old English dēagian, from the noun.

entries.meaning: A colourant, especially one that has an affinity to the substrate to which it is applied.

verbs.description: dye (third-person singular simple present dyes, present participle dyeing, simple past and past participle dyed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To colour with dye, or as if with dye.
examples: You look different. Have you had your hair dyed?

entries.meaning: Alternative spelling of die (“singular of dice”)
examples: If a dye were marked with one figure or number of spots on four sides, and with another figure or number of spots on the two remaining sides, it would be more probable, that the former would turn up than the latter;
